title: Hyaloid artery
text:
The hyaloid artery is a branch of the <a href="ophthalmic%20artery">ophthalmic artery</a>, which is itself a branch of the <a href="internal%20carotid%20artery">internal carotid artery</a>. It is contained within the <a href="optic%20stalk">optic stalk</a> of the <a href="human%20eye">eye</a> and extends from the <a href="optic%20disc">optic disc</a> through the <a href="vitreous%20humor">vitreous humor</a> to the <a href="lens%20%28anatomy%29">lens</a>. Usually fully regressed before <a href="childbirth">birth</a>, its purpose is to supply nutrients to the developing lens in the growing <a href="fetus">fetus</a>.
During the tenth week of development in humans (time varies depending on species), the lens grows independent of a blood supply and the hyaloid artery usually regresses. Its proximal portion remains as the central artery of the <a href="retina">retina</a>. Regression of the hyaloid artery leaves a clear central zone through the vitreous humor, called the <a href="hyaloid%20canal">hyaloid canal</a> or Cloquet's canal. Cloquet's canal is named after the French physician <a href="Jules%20Germain%20Cloquet">Jules Germain Cloquet</a> (1790–1883) who first described it.
Occasionally the artery may not fully regress, resulting in the condition "persistent hyaloid artery". More commonly, small remnants of the artery may remain. Free remnants can sometimes be seen as "<a href="floater">floater</a>s". An anterior remnant of the hyaloid artery can be seen in some people as "Mittendorf's dot", a small pinpoint-like scar on the posterior surface of the lens. A posterior remnant may be seen where the artery left the optic disc, and is known as <a href="Bergmeister%27s%20papilla">Bergmeister's papilla</a>.
